docs.lead_paragraph: Charles M. Schulz, the creator of ''Peanuts,'' the tender and sage comic strip starring Charlie Brown and Snoopy that is read by 355 million people around the world, died in his sleep on Saturday night at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif., just hours before his last cartoon ran in the Sunday newspapers. He was 77. The cause of death was colon cancer, said Paige Braddock, creative director for Charles M. Schulz Creative Associates.

headline.main: Charles M. Schulz, 'Peanuts' Creator, Dies at 77

docs.abstract: Charles M Schulz, creator of 'Peanuts' comic strip read by 355 million people worldwide, dies of colon cancer at age 77, hours after final cartoon runs in Sunday newspapers; drew cartoon for nearly half century; final strip, which apppeared on February 13, carried signed farewell; photos; cartoons (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: NETSCAPE is back. It never really went away, of course. But more than a year has passed -- at least a generation in Internet time -- since Netscape, the weakened Internet software company, was acquired by America Online, leading to an exodus of top executives and programmers. Now Netscape has released a preview version of its next-generation browser software, Netscape 6.0. The final version is not expected for about six months, but this first trial version, which is available free for Windows, Macintosh and Linux-based computers at www.netscape.com, at least indicates that Microsoft's market-leading browser software, Internet Explorer, still has a formidable rival.
docs.abstract: Peter H Lewis column assesses preview version of Netscape's next-generation Internet browser; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to buying plants, I don't like to order them on the Web. If it's something simple I'm after, like more purple coneflowers or a couple of Miss Kim lilacs, I'll head for a favorite nursery and wander down those aisles of trees, shrubs and perennials. I flirt with all kinds of plants I don't need, touching the leaves, sizing up their height, branching, color and general health. I open their jaws and look at their teeth. I spend a lot of money on things I didn't come for. But that's part of the joy of gardening. It's easy enough to spend money on the Internet, but you don't experience any of these sensual pleasures. In fact, too often, it feels like work. There I am on some gorgeous day, hunched over my desk, clicking my mouse, straining my eyes at a rather blurry picture of Hydrangea paniculata Tardiva, which I want, desperately. I add the $19 bare-root Hydrangea to my ''wheelbarrow'' and continue down the list.

headline.main: Waiting for the Web To Be a Garden Spot

docs.abstract: Anne Raver column on browsing and shopping for garden plants on line; says she still prefers nurseries and catalogs; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, search engines seemed like the Web's salvation. Today, they need some saviors of their own. When search engines first appeared, they were hailed for accomplishing two things that could not be done by people on any large scale: Search engines use software agents to find and index sites almost as soon as they appeared. And they could almost instantaneously match a far-flung Web page with a single keyword typed into a beckoning search box.
docs.abstract: Web search engines are becoming more dependent on human judgment because computers and software cannot find and index all the new sites in the ever-expanding Web and because they are not yet at the point where they can analyze a Web document and, without any human interference, instantly understand what that document is about; librarians at Northern Light constantly fine-tune their directory structure and come up with names of categories for sorting Web sites; Google and other system may evaluate sites according to how frequently they are visited or the paths by which they are visited; information scientists see danger of human bias and 'tyranny of the majority' in such approaches; photo; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Search Engine as Cyborg'' (June 29), about the way many search engines are combining human judgment with search software, played down Google, even though according to the article, Google is the only search engine that isn't a ''cop-out.'' O.K., so your article was about cyborgs, part robot and part human. But are cyborgs good? No! Are they a cop-out? Yes!
docs.abstract: John Pritchard letter defends Google's Internet search software against criticisms voiced in June 29 article

docs.lead_paragraph: Recently, an article in a newspaper stated that ''at least 60 million people visit Internet health sites each year.'' This is not entirely accurate. I visit Internet health sites 60 million times each year. Until the development of the Internet, I kept my unhealthy interest in check by limiting my medical library to a few essential texts. That's the same principle that keeps me from bringing a deluxe Whitman's sampler box into my house: I would eat it all in one sitting. But now, it is as if my computer were spewing mocha cremes at me.

headline.main: Hyperlinks for Hypochondriacs: Old Malady in a New World

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Salon.com revamped its Web site in May, readers greeted it with hundreds of e-mail complaints. They criticized the horizontal scrolling, the small type and the headlines that no longer linked directly to articles. Within days, Salon's editor, David Talbot, posted a note to readers saying, ''You win!'' and the site reverted to some of its old design.

headline.main: A Message to Web Designers: If It Ain't Broke, Don't Fix It

docs.abstract: Web users are becoming increasingly impatient with constant face lifts of their favorite sites or with sites that are difficult to navigate; designers note importance of reliability, speed, customization, and anonymity to increasingly sophisticated clients; biggest complaint about Web design is information overload, usually when companies have concentrated too much on design and content and not enough on how information is structured; revamping of sites can cause customer revolts, as evidenced by recent barrage of criticism that forced Salon.com to undo many of changes it made to its site; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Web-enabled cell phones can now be used to view any of the estimated 1.6 billion pages on the Web with a new service from the Google search engine. The Google service, which was introduced last week, translates standard Web pages into wireless markup language, the programming language used by most cell phone browsers. Mobile searchers who go to the Google site can enter the address of any Web page and it will be translated and displayed. Some Nextel Communications phones began displaying the Google search option on Aug. 1. Marty Katz (NYT)
docs.abstract: New service from Google, Internet search engine, will allow Web-enabled cell phones to view any of estimated 1.6 billion pages on Web (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: I AM looking for a piano lamp that has a long arm that you can adjust to cast really strong light on sheet music. The lamp has to be small enough to fit on a small shelf, and it should not tip over and fall onto the floor constantly like the last one (which broke). Also, it cannot be ugly. Is that too much to ask?

headline.main: Site Invites Shoppers To Wax Eloquent

docs.lead_paragraph: I AM a big defender of the dress. Suffering from three children, a dog, two cats and a suicidal streak that prompted me to agree last week to become a class mother, I am grateful to any single article of clothing that takes less than 30 seconds to put on but is efficient enough to function as an entire outfit. Make that an entire identity. With a mere dress, you can transform yourself into a businesswoman, a carpooling mom, an Audrey Hepburn wannabe or a princess.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's probably safe to say the Internet has saved Americans millions of gallons in fuel, formerly wasted by people driving aimlessly along back roads with directions from someone who never quite figured out the whole left-right thing. By now, in fact, it's second nature to many people to get onto the Web for door-to-door directions before they leave the house on a long driving trip. But in their haste to hit the road, a lot of those people -- myself included -- have never bothered to pause on any of the mapping Web sites, and, well, get lost. A few years ago, such exploration would have yielded little, as sites like mapquest .com and mapsonus.com provided mostly basic features like directions and maps. But that's changing quickly. More recently, the map sites have expanded their offerings to include much of the information you'd want before leaving, including attractions along the way, road construction, weather maps, gas station stops, accommodations and even travel games to keep the back seat from becoming a war zone.

headline.main: Turn Left at the Shoe Store . . .

docs.abstract: Road mapping sites on Internet improve thanks to new technologies and competition from off-line companies; new features include information on attractions along the way, road construction, weather conditions, gas stations, accommodations and travel games; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN I was growing up, my family greeted the arrival of the holiday season with a sacred tradition: we shopped. We also cared deeply for the ritual of wrapping, which generally led to bitter accusations that someone was hoarding the expensive silver foil paper and counter-charges of excessive cellophane tape usage. The buildup culminated in a frenzied three-minute celebration, as 40 assembled relatives simultaneously ripped open 400 gifts, filling the shared airspace with so much discarded packaging that one year my mother lost sight of the baby. Luckily, my father rushed in with a Online Shopper squad of cleanup specialists, consisting of my brothers armed with jumbo Hefty bags. They shouted coordinates -- ''There's an unsecured gift card at four o'clock'' -- into their new walkie-talkies and removed stray ribbons from the necks of the weak or elderly.

headline.main: Ouija Boards To Motherboards In Online Bazaar

docs.lead_paragraph: The mobile Internet has been promoted as the Web untethered, unstrung and unwired: the content of the World Wide Web available anytime, anywhere on a cell phone, hand-held computer, laptop or pager. The truth is, extending the experience of a Web-enabled desktop computer to a mobile environment is too good to be true for now. In the United States, at least, consumer response to slow-loading services like sports scores and stock quotes on tiny cell-phone screens has been anemic.

headline.kicker: COMING TO GRIPS WITH THE WEB: WIRELESS ACCESS

docs.abstract: Mobile Web remains promise; consumer response to slow-loading services like sports scores and stock quotes on tiny cell-phone screens has been anemic; many of start-ups are seeking to make mobile Internet easier to use by building their own portals, search engines and e-mail programs that could be used by any wireless customer, regardless of carrier; clash between these two camps is almost inevitable; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a wired world, an old-fashioned letter to Santa Claus can seem sadly, well, old-fashioned. First-class mail can take days, and paper-and-envelope communiques can be mangled or lost. But e-mail goes through in a twinkle, faster than Dasher, Dancer, Donder and Blitzen on a long winter's night of rooftop hopscotching. So if you thought that not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse, remember that ''A Visit From St. Nicholas'' was written long before the point-and-click age, when cursors on some Santa Web sites turn into heads of reindeer.

headline.main: He Knows If You've Been Naughty, But You Can Still Send Him E-Mail

docs.abstract: More and more children are using e-mail to write to Santa Claus; more than 20 Santa sites are on the Web, all heavily commercialized; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: These people see the future every day. For the most part, they are quite young. They are universally precocious. And their very livelihoods revolve around reading, thinking and talking about stuff most of us might consider fanciful, bordering on incomprehensible.

docs.lead_paragraph: Although people who use wireless Palm organizers are able to get access to Internet data like stock quotations and restaurant listings, the information has a somewhat fragmented feel because it comes from different sources on the Web. This week, however, Palm released MyPalm, a wireless portal that aims to help users make better sense of the Web. MyPalm can be downloaded free at my.palm .net and then loaded onto any Palm with wireless capability. In addition to letting users organize all of their Web and e-mail applications in one place, MyPalm has wireless synchronization so a Palm will automatically display schedule changes made on Palm desktop software on a home or office PC.

headline.main: MyPalm Can Help You Become More Organized

docs.abstract: New MyPalm wireless portal allows user to organize all of their Web and e-mail applications in one place (S)
